CAESIUM

Caesium was discovered by Robert Wilhelm Bunsen and Gustav Robert Kirchhoff, German chemists, in 1860 through the spectroscopic analysis of Durkheim mineral water.

Obtaining pure Caesium is difficult since Caesium ores are frequently contaminated with rubidium, an element that is chemically similar to Caesium.

Metallic Caesium is too reactive to easily handle and is usually sold in the form of Caesium azide. Caesium is recovered from Caesium azide by heating it.

Caesium reacts violently with water and ice, forming Caesium hydroxide (CsOH). Caesium hydroxide is the strongest base known and will attack glass.

Caesium (Cs)
Atomic Number 55
Atomic Weight 132.905
Melting Point 28.44°C
Boiling Point 671°C
Density 1.93 g/cm3
Period Number 6
Group Number 1
